content.description:
SDS under the roof on crimps and move right to slopers and horrible sloping crimps as you compress up the prow. Careful foot placement will make this somewhat easier. Squeezing for all you are worth make a big move to the huge bucket jug at the apex of the roof and finish as per Queensnake with a mantel. 
  
 The hardest classic at HWLD and a really excellent problem. 
  
 Unfortunately, The Crab boulder shifted over the 2015-2016 Winter and this problem looks to be no more.

Under the roof of the Crab Boulder
pad or two under the roof and under the apex

Stand start on high crimps, pull on with high feet and move up the short slab to top out. Pulling onto the problem is the crux and will feel significantly easier if you are tall/have strong fingers. 
  
 Traversing in from the right on slopers is "Moonwart" V4.

Located on the lake facing side of the Crab Boulder. Start on the obvious chalked crimps in the middle of the slab.
pad

Rising traverse along the SE side of The Crab boulder. SDS on the left and follow jugs and slopers at the lip of the boulder until the apex of the overhang at the right end. From a huge jug move up to pockets on the blunt arete and mantel. The crux comes at the end, especially if you get pumped traversing across the lip. 
  
 The closest thing to a warm-up in the area, completing the traverse to the jug gets the blood flowing even without the topout mantel. 
  
 Unfortunately, The Crab boulder shifted over the 2015-2016 Winter and this problem looks to be no more. The jugs at the lip of the boulder that were previously used to traverse are now less than a foot off the rock shelf, and pretty much underwater when the water level is high.

Located on the Crab Boulder, Shelf Beach
pad under the apex of the roof for the topout mantel

pathTokens: Halfway Log Dump (Bruce Peninsula National Park)

content.description:
One of the most aesthetic boulders at HWLD it also marks the beginning of the designated climbing area. Only has a few problems, but two are classics! 
  
 Unfortunately, the crab shifted (presumably this winter/spring) and the two classic problems are no more.
